title: Jiangsu Province, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, and China Chamber of Commerce donate anti-epidemic materials to Ethiopia (Linked to Project ID#94637, 94638)
description: On October 23, 2020, Ethiopia's largest state, Oromia, received a large donation of anti-COVID-19 medical supplies granted by local Chinese governments and Chinese businesses. Jiangsu Province (Project ID#93083), Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region (Project ID#94637), and the China Chamber of Commerce in Ethiopia (CCCE) (Project ID#94638) collectively donated 20 ventilators, 350,000 medical masks, 4,000 protective suits, and some other advanced medical supplies. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. Because the Jiangsu Province, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region and the China Chamber of Commerce in Ethiopia (CCCE) all contributed an unknown number of supplies to this donation, AidData assumes each donor made an equal contribution. The total value of the donation is estimated to be $657,116.80, with each donor contributing an estimated USD 219,038.93 (USD 657,116.80 / 3 known contributors = USD 219,038.93).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Jiangsu Province, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, and China Chamber of Commerce donate anti-epidemic materials to Ethiopia (Linked to Project ID#94637, 94638)

# Description
On October 23, 2020, Ethiopia's largest state, Oromia, received a large donation of anti-COVID-19 medical supplies granted by local Chinese governments and Chinese businesses. Jiangsu Province (Project ID#93083), Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region (Project ID#94637), and the China Chamber of Commerce in Ethiopia (CCCE) (Project ID#94638) collectively donated 20 ventilators, 350,000 medical masks, 4,000 protective suits, and some other advanced medical supplies. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for public health purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of ventilators, medical masks, protective suits, and other medical supplies for COVID-19 response

title: Hunan Construction Engineering Group (HNCEG) donates half a million birr worth of anti-epidemic supplies to Ethiopia in May 2020
description: In May 2020, the Hunan Construction Engineering Group (HNCEG) donated anti-epidemic supplies which were worth half a million birr to Ethiopia. The specific type and amount of the supplies are unknown.

title: Chinese government donates medical materials to Ethiopia in April 2020 (Linked to Project ID#91742)
description: On April 16, 2020, a batch of medical materials donated by the Chinese Government to the Ethiopian Government was delivered to the Addis Ababa Bole International Airport. The monetary value of the donation is unknown. The same flight also carried the medical team sent by China to Ethiopia to support the fight against Covid-19 (see Project ID#91742).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese government donates medical materials to Ethiopia in April 2020 (Linked to Project ID#91742)

# Description
On April 16, 2020, a batch of medical materials donated by the Chinese Government to the Ethiopian Government was delivered to the Addis Ababa Bole International Airport. The monetary value of the donation is unknown. The same flight also carried the medical team sent by China to Ethiopia to support the fight against Covid-19 (see Project ID#91742).
justification: Project involves donation of medical materials and support for healthcare, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Medical materials donation, healthcare support focus, no energy-related components

title: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation, Dongguan municipal government and four Chinese companies jointly donate anti-epidemic supplies to Ethiopia in June 2020 (Linked to Project ID#94604, 94605, 94606, 94607, 93033)
description: On June 2, 2020, Dongguan municipal government (Project ID#93033), Huajian International Light Industry City (Project ID#94604), Transsion Manufacturing Private Limited Company (PLC) (Project ID#94605), Huawei Technologies Ethiopia PLC (Project ID#94606), the Tencent Foundation (Project ID#94607), and China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) (Project ID#94608) donated 520,000 masks and medical supplies to the municipal government of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The donation also included unspecified amounts of disinfectant as well as forehead thermometers and respirators. The deputy mayor of Addis Ababa received the donations in a handover ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. Because the Dongguan municipal government, Huajian International Light Industry City, Transsion Manufacturing Private Limited Company (PLC), Huawei Technologies Ethiopia PLC, the Tencent Foundation and China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) all contributed an unknown number of supplies to this donation, AidData assumes each donor made an equal contribution. The total value of the donation is estimated to be $156,000.00, with each donor contributing an estimated USD 26,000.00 (USD 156,000.00 / 6 known contributors = USD 26,000.00).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation, Dongguan municipal government and four Chinese companies jointly donate anti-epidemic supplies to Ethiopia in June 2020 (Linked to Project ID#94604, 94605, 94606, 94607, 93033)

# Description
On June 2, 2020, Dongguan municipal government (Project ID#93033), Huajian International Light Industry City (Project ID#94604), Transsion Manufacturing Private Limited Company (PLC) (Project ID#94605), Huawei Technologies Ethiopia PLC (Project ID#94606), the Tencent Foundation (Project ID#94607), and China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) (Project ID#94608) donated 520,000 masks and medical supplies to the municipal government of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The donation also included unspecified amounts of disinfectant as well as forehead thermometers and respirators. The deputy mayor of Addis Ababa received the donations in a handover ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for public health purposes, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: 520,000 masks, medical supplies, disinfectant, forehead thermometers, and respirators donated for anti-epidemic purposes

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Ethiopia in 2020
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Ethiopia signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is $52,389,790.   However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 3-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period).   Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Ethiopia. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount in 2020 is based on the amount disclosed in the Annual Public Sector Debt Portfolio Analysis for the Year 2020/21 published by Ethiopia’s Ministry of Finance (https://www.mofed.gov.et/media/filer_public/da/3f/da3f3cc8-5358-438b-91cc-b46cb2f3b104/1final_ethiopias_dpa_no_22_2021_1.pdf). 3. According to Public Sector Debt Statistical Bulletin No. 41 published by Ethiopia's Ministry of Finance, it did not make debt service payments to the creditors that participated in DSSI from May 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Ethiopia in 2020

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Ethiopia signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is $52,389,790.   However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 3-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period).   Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial restructuring and COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Government donates USD 18,000 to Ethiopia through the International Organization for Migration in May 2020
description: In May 2020, Chinese government provides USD 18,000 as Emergency Shelter Support for Displaced Persons in Ethiopia.  This project is captured in UNOCHA Financial Tracking Service as Flow ID #219158.
